awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sarah Michel from the University of Maryland Baltimore to investigate how the trace metal zinc is involved in the important biological process of RNA regulation. All living systems require RNA to be processed into different molecular forms. Genome sequencing has identified a family of proteins called 'non-classical' zinc finger (ZF) proteins that play key roles in regulating RNA.  Two proteins from this family, TTP and CPS30, are investigated in vitro and in cells to determine how zinc binding affects RNA processing. These studies help define general principles of metal directed protein RNA regulation in living systems and identify how toxic metals disrupt these fundamental biological processes.  Graduate student participants receive training at the interface of chemistry and biology using cutting edge experimental techniques.  A successful outreach program called SIMSI developed by the PI with a women's college in Baltimore, which provides mini-graduate school experiences and mentoring continues. In addition, a new outreach workshop called "Minding Your Metals" that draws inspiration form the Flint, MI drinking water crisis is developed for underrepresented minority (URM) students from three Baltimore City urban public middle schools. Graduate students are involved in all outreach efforts, and will be trained in communicating findings and conveying scientific principles to audiences with different levels of science knowledge. 

This proposal is focused on the CCCH class of non-classical zinc finger (ZF) proteins. Two CCCH ZFs, tristetraprolin (TTP) and cleavage and polyadenylation specificity factor 30 (CPSF30) are investigated. TTP is a key player in the regulation of inflammation, when reactive oxygen species are elevated, and outstanding questions include the roles of metal ions (native and toxic), and the participation of reactive oxygen species and reactive sulfur species in the structure and function of TTP. CPSF30 is involved in pre- mRNA processing, and contains a 2Fe-2S cluster, in addition to zinc sites. The PI (1) determines how metal ions, reactive oxygen species and reactive sulfur species modulate TTP function in vitro and in cells and (2) determines the mechanism of RNA recognition for CPSF30 by deciphering the functional roles of the 2Fe-2S cluster, the CCCH domains and the CCHC domain. Biochemical, biophysical, structural and cell based approaches are taken, including fluorescence anisotropy to measure protein/RNA binding, native ESI-MS and ICP-MS to determine stoichiometry, cryo-ESI-MS to elucidate reactivity with reactive oxygen and sulfur species, HDX/MS and crosslinking/ESI-MS to identify structural changes upon RNA binding, and cellular reporter assays to translate in vitro findings to cells.

por.por_cntn:
The 'trace metal' zinc plays important roles in biology and is the second most common metal found in biological systems. One critical role of zinc is as a structural co-factor for proteins. These proteins, called zinc fingers (ZFs), are the most common metal co-factored regulatory protein found in eukaryotes. ZFs function to control numerous biological processes including inflammation, viral replication, tumor suppression, and neuronal development.  ZFs are defined based upon their amino acid sequence. All ZFs contain four cysteine and/or histidine ligands.  Genome sequencing has revealed that ZFs are ubiquitous (e.g., 5% of all human proteins are ZFs); however, many ZFs are poorly studied.  This project focused on emerging class of ZFs called 'CCCH' type ZFs, due to their 3-Cysteine; 1-Histidine sequence motif. CCCH ZFs are involved in RNA regulation, and in this work our group focused on two CCCH type ZFs: tristetraprolin (TTP) and cleavage and polyadenylation specificity factor 30 (CPSF30). TTP regulates cytokines during inflammation by binding to cytokine mRNAs and targeting for degradation. We sought to understand how metal ions and reactive sulfur species, which are elevated during inflammation, modulate TTP function. To investigate interactions of Zn-TTP with exogenous metals, we had to overcome the challenge of studying metal exchange with ZFs. Because Zn2+ is d10 and spectroscopically silent, we do not have a ready spectroscopic handle. To overcome this hurdle, we developed two new approaches: a spin-filter ICP-MS approach and a native-ESI-MS monitored titration. These methods allowed us to monitor metal exchange, determine stoichometry, and understand the role of RNA binding with TTP in metal exchange.  We discovered that some metals (e.g., Cd and Au) can exchange with Zn, and that RNA binding can block this exchange. This approach has the potential to be applied to studies of metal exchange with other ZFs and metalloproteins in general, offering new tools for bioinorganic chemists.  We also investigated reactive sulfur species interactions with TTP using cryo-ESI-MS. We discovered that H2S reacts with Zn-TTP-2D in an O2 dependent manner yielding persulfidated cysteine residues which are then further oxidized to disulfides, resulting in loss of RNA binding. These data provided evidence of persulfidation of ZF proteins by H2S, which is emerging as an important gasotransmitter. CPSF30 is a 'CCCH' type ZF that regulates pre-mRNA processing. CPSF30 unique in that it also contains a 'CCHC' type ZF (a zinc knuckle domain) and we have discovered that one of the CCCH ZF sites houses a 2Fe-2S site. We sought to determine the mechanism of metal mediated RNA recognition by CPSF30. We isolated full length CPSF30 for the first time and discovered bipartite binding whereby the CCCH domains regulate AU-rich RNA sequences and the CCHC domains regulate U-rich RNA sequences present in pre-mRNA. This research provided a molecular level understanding of the relationships between metal ion binding, protein folding, and RNA recognition for TTP and CPSF30. These studies helped define principles for metal-cofactored protein regulation. In addition, our laboratory developed ICP-MS as a tool to measure metal speciation in biological systems, and collaborated with numerous laboratories both at Maryland and in the Mid-Atlantic to apply this methodology to metallobiochemical problems

Our research findings were disseminated in publications and presentations, contributing to the advancement of scientific knowledge. Student at various stages of their academic careers - high school, undergraduate and graduate students - participated in the research. The PI organized a yearly outreach program, 'Spring into Maryland Science' or SIMSI, a partnership with a local Women's college, Notre Dame of Maryland, to provide hands on mini-graduate school experiences, a 'Women in Science' panel and summer research opportunities.  The PI developed an activity called 'Minding your Metals' with undergraduate, high school and middle school student participants. This activity was modeled on the citizen scientist effort to measure metals in the drinking water in Flint, MI, where lead was discovered to be elevated to toxic levels. The 'Minding your Metals' activity involved students collecting tap water samples from different parts of Baltimore City, measuring metal content using ICP-MS, and analyzing data. The activity was published in 'The Journal of Chemical Education' where it can serve as a resource for colleagues at other institutions to advance science education activities.
